segment.source: Storyboarded animations
segment.target: Storyboarded animations

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Storyboarded animations are not just animations in the visual sense.
segment.target: Storyboarded animations are not just animations in the visual sense.

segment.source: A storyboarded animation is a way to change the value of a dependency property as a function of time.
segment.target: A storyboarded animation is a way to change the value of a dependency property as a function of time.

segment.source: One of the main reasons you might need a storyboarded animation that's not from the animation library is to define the visual state for a control, as part of a control template or page definition.
segment.target: One of the main reasons you might need a storyboarded animation that's not from the animation library is to define the visual state for a control, as part of a control template or page definition.

segment.source: Differences with Silverlight and WPF
segment.target: Differences with Silverlight and WPF

segment.source: If you are familiar with Microsoft Silverlight or Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF), read this section; otherwise, you can skip it.
segment.target: If you are familiar with Microsoft Silverlight or Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF), read this section; otherwise, you can skip it.

segment.source: In general, creating storyboarded animations in a Windows Runtime app is like Silverlight or WPF.
segment.target: In general, creating storyboarded animations in a Windows Runtime app is like Silverlight or WPF.

segment.source: But there are a number of important differences:
segment.target: But there are a number of important differences:

segment.source: Storyboarded animations are not the only way to visually animate a UI, nor are they necessarily the easiest way for app developers to do so.
segment.target: Storyboarded animations are not the only way to visually animate a UI, nor are they necessarily the easiest way for app developers to do so.

segment.source: Rather than using storyboarded animations it's often a better design practice to use theme animations and transition animations.
segment.target: Rather than using storyboarded animations it's often a better design practice to use theme animations and transition animations.

segment.source: These can quickly create recommended UI animations without getting into the intricacies of animation property targeting.
segment.target: These can quickly create recommended UI animations without getting into the intricacies of animation property targeting.

segment.source: For more info see Animations overview.
segment.target: For more info see Animations overview.

segment.source: In the Windows Runtime, many XAML controls include theme animations and transition animations as part of their built-in behavior.
segment.target: In the Windows Runtime, many XAML controls include theme animations and transition animations as part of their built-in behavior.

segment.source: For the most part, WPF and Silverlight controls didn't have a default animation behavior.
segment.target: For the most part, WPF and Silverlight controls didn't have a default animation behavior.

segment.source: Not all custom animations you create can run by default in a Windows Runtime app, if the animation system determines that the animation might cause bad performance in your UI.
segment.target: Not all custom animations you create can run by default in a Windows Runtime app, if the animation system determines that the animation might cause bad performance in your UI.

segment.source: Animations where the system determines there could be a performance impact are called dependent animations.
segment.target: Animations where the system determines there could be a performance impact are called dependent animations.

segment.source: It's dependent because the clocking of your animation is directly working against the UI thread, which is also where active user input and other updates are trying to apply the runtime changes to UI.
segment.target: It's dependent because the clocking of your animation is directly working against the UI thread, which is also where active user input and other updates are trying to apply the runtime changes to UI.

segment.source: A dependent animation that's consuming extensive system resources on the UI thread can make the app appear unresponsive in certain situations.
segment.target: A dependent animation that's consuming extensive system resources on the UI thread can make the app appear unresponsive in certain situations.

segment.source: If your animation causes a layout change or otherwise has the potential to impact performance on the UI thread, you often need to explicitly enable the animation to see it run.
segment.target: If your animation causes a layout change or otherwise has the potential to impact performance on the UI thread, you often need to explicitly enable the animation to see it run.

segment.source: That's what the EnableDependentAnimation property on specific animation classes is for.
segment.target: That's what the EnableDependentAnimation property on specific animation classes is for.

segment.source: See Dependent and independent animations for more info.
segment.target: See Dependent and independent animations for more info.

segment.source: Custom easing functions are not currently supported in the Windows Runtime.
segment.target: Custom easing functions are not currently supported in the Windows Runtime.

segment.source: Defining storyboarded animations
segment.target: Defining storyboarded animations

segment.source: A storyboarded animation is a way to change the value of a dependency property as a function of time.
segment.target: A storyboarded animation is a way to change the value of a dependency property as a function of time.

segment.source: The property you are animating is not always a property that directly affects the UI of your app.
segment.target: The property you are animating is not always a property that directly affects the UI of your app.

segment.source: But since XAML is about defining UI for an app, usually it is a UI-related property you are animating.
segment.target: But since XAML is about defining UI for an app, usually it is a UI-related property you are animating.

segment.source: For example, you can animate the angle of a **RotateTransform**, or the color value of a button's background.
segment.target: For example, you can animate the angle of a **RotateTransform**, or the color value of a button's background.

segment.source: One of the main reasons you might be defining a storyboarded animation is if you are a control author or are re-templating a control, and you are defining visual states.
segment.target: One of the main reasons you might be defining a storyboarded animation is if you are a control author or are re-templating a control, and you are defining visual states.

segment.source: For more info, see Storyboarded animations for visual states.
segment.target: For more info, see Storyboarded animations for visual states.

segment.source: Whether you are defining visual states or a custom animation for an app, the concepts and APIs for storyboarded animations that are described in this topic mostly apply to either.
segment.target: Whether you are defining visual states or a custom animation for an app, the concepts and APIs for storyboarded animations that are described in this topic mostly apply to either.

segment.source: In order to be animated, the property you are targeting with a storyboarded animation must be a dependency property.
segment.target: In order to be animated, the property you are targeting with a storyboarded animation must be a dependency property.

segment.source: A dependency property is a key feature of the Windows Runtime XAML implementation.
segment.target: A dependency property is a key feature of the Windows Runtime XAML implementation.

segment.source: The writeable properties of most common UI elements are typically implemented as dependency properties, so that you can animate them, apply data-bound values, or apply a **Style** and target the property with a **Setter**.
segment.target: The writeable properties of most common UI elements are typically implemented as dependency properties, so that you can animate them, apply data-bound values, or apply a **Style** and target the property with a **Setter**.

segment.source: For more info about how dependency properties work, see Dependency properties overview.
segment.target: For more info about how dependency properties work, see Dependency properties overview.

segment.source: Most of the time, you define a storyboarded animation by writing XAML.
segment.target: Most of the time, you define a storyboarded animation by writing XAML.

segment.source: If you use a tool such as Microsoft Visual Studio, it will produce the XAML for you.
segment.target: If you use a tool such as Microsoft Visual Studio, it will produce the XAML for you.

segment.source: It's possible to define a storyboarded animation using code too, but that's less common.
segment.target: It's possible to define a storyboarded animation using code too, but that's less common.

segment.source: Let's look at a simple example.
segment.target: Let's look at a simple example.

segment.source: In this XAML example, the **Opacity** property is animated on a particular **Rectangle** object.
segment.target: In this XAML example, the **Opacity** property is animated on a particular **Rectangle** object.

segment.source: Identifying the object to animate
segment.target: Identifying the object to animate

segment.source: In the previous example, the storyboard was animating the **Opacity** property of a **Rectangle**.
segment.target: In the previous example, the storyboard was animating the **Opacity** property of a **Rectangle**.

segment.source: You don't declare the animations on the object itself.
segment.target: You don't declare the animations on the object itself.

segment.source: Instead you do this within the animation definition of a storyboard.
segment.target: Instead you do this within the animation definition of a storyboard.

segment.source: Storyboards are usually defined in XAML that's not in the immediately vicinity of the XAML UI definition of the object to animate.
segment.target: Storyboards are usually defined in XAML that's not in the immediately vicinity of the XAML UI definition of the object to animate.

segment.source: Instead, they're usually set up as a XAML resource.
segment.target: Instead, they're usually set up as a XAML resource.

segment.source: To connect an animation to a target, you reference the target by its identifying programming name.
segment.target: To connect an animation to a target, you reference the target by its identifying programming name.

segment.source: You should always apply the x:Name attribute in the XAML UI definition to name the object that you want to animate.
segment.target: You should always apply the x:Name attribute in the XAML UI definition to name the object that you want to animate.

segment.source: You then target the object to animate by setting **Storyboard.TargetName** within the animation definition.
segment.target: You then target the object to animate by setting **Storyboard.TargetName** within the animation definition.

segment.source: For the value of Storyboard.TargetName, you use the name string of the target object, which is what you set earlier and elsewhere with x:Name attribute.
segment.target: For the value of Storyboard.TargetName, you use the name string of the target object, which is what you set earlier and elsewhere with x:Name attribute.

segment.source: Targeting the dependency property to animate
segment.target: Targeting the dependency property to animate

segment.source: You set a value for **Storyboard.TargetProperty** in the animation.
segment.target: You set a value for **Storyboard.TargetProperty** in the animation.

segment.source: This determines which specific property of the targeted object is animated.
segment.target: This determines which specific property of the targeted object is animated.

segment.source: Sometimes you need to target a property that's not an immediate property of the target object, but that is nested more deeply in an object-property relationship.
segment.target: Sometimes you need to target a property that's not an immediate property of the target object, but that is nested more deeply in an object-property relationship.

segment.source: You often need to do this in order to drill down into a set of contributing object and property values until you can reference a property type that can be animated (**Double**, **Point**, **Color**.
segment.target: You often need to do this in order to drill down into a set of contributing object and property values until you can reference a property type that can be animated (**Double**, **Point**, **Color**.

segment.source: This concept is called indirect targeting, and the syntax for targeting a property in this way is known as a property path.
segment.target: This concept is called indirect targeting, and the syntax for targeting a property in this way is known as a property path.

segment.source: Here's an example.
segment.target: Here's an example.

segment.source: One common scenario for a storyboarded animation is to change the color of a part of an app UI or control in order to represent that the control is in a particular state.
segment.target: One common scenario for a storyboarded animation is to change the color of a part of an app UI or control in order to represent that the control is in a particular state.

segment.source: Say you want to animate the **Foreground** of a **TextBlock**, so that it turns from red to green.
segment.target: Say you want to animate the **Foreground** of a **TextBlock**, so that it turns from red to green.

segment.source: You'd expect that a **ColorAnimation** is involved, and that's correct.
segment.target: You'd expect that a **ColorAnimation** is involved, and that's correct.

segment.source: However, none of the properties on UI elements that affect the object's color are actually of type **Color**.
segment.target: However, none of the properties on UI elements that affect the object's color are actually of type **Color**.

segment.source: Instead, they're of type **Brush**.
segment.target: Instead, they're of type **Brush**.

segment.source: So what you actually need to target for animation is the **Color** property of the **SolidColorBrush** class, which is a Brush-derived type that's typically used for these color-related UI properties.
segment.target: So what you actually need to target for animation is the **Color** property of the **SolidColorBrush** class, which is a Brush-derived type that's typically used for these color-related UI properties.

segment.source: And here's what that looks like in terms of forming a property path for your animation's property targeting:
segment.target: And here's what that looks like in terms of forming a property path for your animation's property targeting:

segment.source: Here's how to think of this syntax in terms of its parts:
segment.target: Here's how to think of this syntax in terms of its parts:

segment.source: Each set of () parentheses encloses a property name.
segment.target: Each set of () parentheses encloses a property name.

segment.source: Within the property name, there's a dot, and that dot separates a type name and a property name, so that the property you're identifying is unambiguous.
segment.target: Within the property name, there's a dot, and that dot separates a type name and a property name, so that the property you're identifying is unambiguous.

segment.source: The dot in the middle, the one that's not inside parentheses, is a step.
segment.target: The dot in the middle, the one that's not inside parentheses, is a step.

segment.source: This is interpreted by the syntax to mean, take the value of the first property (which is an object), step into its object model, and target a specific sub-property of the first property's value.
segment.target: This is interpreted by the syntax to mean, take the value of the first property (which is an object), step into its object model, and target a specific sub-property of the first property's value.

segment.source: Here's a list of animation targeting scenarios where you'll probably be using indirect property targeting, and some property path strings that approximate the syntax you'll use:
segment.target: Here's a list of animation targeting scenarios where you'll probably be using indirect property targeting, and some property path strings that approximate the syntax you'll use:

segment.source: Animating the **X** value of a **TranslateTransform**, as applied to a **RenderTransform**: (UIElement.RenderTransform).(TranslateTransform.X)
segment.target: Animating the **X** value of a **TranslateTransform**, as applied to a **RenderTransform**: (UIElement.RenderTransform).(TranslateTransform.X)

segment.source: Animating a **Color** within a **GradientStop** of a **LinearGradientBrush**, as applied to a **Fill**: (Shape.Fill).(GradientBrush.GradientStops)[0].(GradientStop.Color)
segment.target: Animating a **Color** within a **GradientStop** of a **LinearGradientBrush**, as applied to a **Fill**: (Shape.Fill).(GradientBrush.GradientStops)[0].(GradientStop.Color)

segment.source: Animating the **X** value of a **TranslateTransform**, which is 1 of 4 transforms in a **TransformGroup**, as applied to a **RenderTransform**:(UIElement.RenderTransform).(TransformGroup.Children)[3].(TranslateTransform.X)
segment.target: Animating the **X** value of a **TranslateTransform**, which is 1 of 4 transforms in a **TransformGroup**, as applied to a **RenderTransform**:(UIElement.RenderTransform).(TransformGroup.Children)[3].(TranslateTransform.X)

segment.source: You'll notice some of these examples use square brackets around numbers.
segment.target: You'll notice some of these examples use square brackets around numbers.

segment.source: This is an indexer.
segment.target: This is an indexer.

segment.source: It indicates that the property name preceding it has a collection as value, and that you want an item (as identified by a zero-based index) from within that collection.
segment.target: It indicates that the property name preceding it has a collection as value, and that you want an item (as identified by a zero-based index) from within that collection.

segment.source: You can also animate XAML attached properties.
segment.target: You can also animate XAML attached properties.

segment.source: Always enclose the full attached property name in parentheses, for example (Canvas.Left).
segment.target: Always enclose the full attached property name in parentheses, for example (Canvas.Left).

segment.source: For more info, see Animating XAML attached properties.
segment.target: For more info, see Animating XAML attached properties.

segment.source: For more info on how to use a property path for indirect targeting of the property to animate, see Property-path syntax or **Storyboard.TargetProperty attached property**.
segment.target: For more info on how to use a property path for indirect targeting of the property to animate, see Property-path syntax or **Storyboard.TargetProperty attached property**.

segment.source: Animation types
segment.target: Animation types

segment.source: The Windows Runtime animation system has three specific types that storyboarded animations can apply to:
segment.target: The Windows Runtime animation system has three specific types that storyboarded animations can apply to:

segment.source:
**Double**
, can be animated with any **DoubleAnimation**
segment.target:
**Double**
, can be animated with any **DoubleAnimation**

segment.source:
**Point**
, can be animated with any **PointAnimation**
segment.target:
**Point**
, can be animated with any **PointAnimation**

segment.source:
**Color**
, can be animated with any **ColorAnimation**
segment.target:
**Color**
, can be animated with any **ColorAnimation**

segment.source: There's also a generalized **Object** animation type for object reference values, which we'll discuss later.
segment.target: There's also a generalized **Object** animation type for object reference values, which we'll discuss later.

segment.source: Specifying the animated values
segment.target: Specifying the animated values

segment.source: So far we've shown you how to target the object and the property to animate, but haven't yet described what the animation does to the property value when it runs.
segment.target: So far we've shown you how to target the object and the property to animate, but haven't yet described what the animation does to the property value when it runs.

segment.source: The animation types we've described are sometimes referred to as From/To/By animations.
segment.target: The animation types we've described are sometimes referred to as From/To/By animations.

segment.source: This means that the animation is changing the value of a property, over time, using one or more of these inputs that come from the animation definition:
segment.target: This means that the animation is changing the value of a property, over time, using one or more of these inputs that come from the animation definition:

segment.source: The value starts at the From value.
segment.target: The value starts at the From value.

segment.source: If you don't specify a From value, the starting value is whatever value the animated property has at the time before the animation runs.
segment.target: If you don't specify a From value, the starting value is whatever value the animated property has at the time before the animation runs.

segment.source: This might be a default value, a value from a style or template, or a value specifically applied by a XAML UI definition or app code.
segment.target: This might be a default value, a value from a style or template, or a value specifically applied by a XAML UI definition or app code.

segment.source: At the end of the animation, the value is the To value.
segment.target: At the end of the animation, the value is the To value.

segment.source: Or, to specify an ending value relative to the starting value, set the By property.
segment.target: Or, to specify an ending value relative to the starting value, set the By property.

segment.source: You'd set this instead of the To property.
segment.target: You'd set this instead of the To property.

segment.source: If you don't specify a To value or a By value, the ending value is whatever value the animated property has at the time before the animation runs.
segment.target: If you don't specify a To value or a By value, the ending value is whatever value the animated property has at the time before the animation runs.

segment.source: In this case you'd better have a From value because otherwise the animation won't change the value at all; its starting and ending values are both the same.
segment.target: In this case you'd better have a From value because otherwise the animation won't change the value at all; its starting and ending values are both the same.

segment.source: An animation typically has at least one of From, By or To but never all three.
segment.target: An animation typically has at least one of From, By or To but never all three.

segment.source: Let's revisit the earlier XAML example and look again at the From and To values, and the Duration.
segment.target: Let's revisit the earlier XAML example and look again at the From and To values, and the Duration.

segment.source: The example is animating the **Opacity** property, and the property type of Opacity is **Double**.
segment.target: The example is animating the **Opacity** property, and the property type of Opacity is **Double**.

segment.source: So the animation to use here is **DoubleAnimation**.
segment.target: So the animation to use here is **DoubleAnimation**.

segment.source: From="1.0" To="0.0" specifies that when the animation runs, the **Opacity** property starts at a value of 1 and animates to 0.
segment.target: From="1.0" To="0.0" specifies that when the animation runs, the **Opacity** property starts at a value of 1 and animates to 0.

segment.source: In other words, in terms of what these **Double** values mean to the Opacity property, this animation will cause the object to start opaque and then fade to transparent.
segment.target: In other words, in terms of what these **Double** values mean to the Opacity property, this animation will cause the object to start opaque and then fade to transparent.

segment.source: Duration="0:0:1" specifies how long the animation lasts, that is, how fast the rectangle fades.
segment.target: Duration="0:0:1" specifies how long the animation lasts, that is, how fast the rectangle fades.

segment.source: A **Duration** property is specified in the form of hours:minutes:seconds.
segment.target: A **Duration** property is specified in the form of hours:minutes:seconds.

segment.source: The time duration in this example is one second.
segment.target: The time duration in this example is one second.

segment.source: For more info about **Duration** values and the XAML syntax, see **Duration**.
segment.target: For more info about **Duration** values and the XAML syntax, see **Duration**.

segment.source: Note For the example we showed, if you were sure that the starting state of the object being animated has **Opacity** always equal to 1, either through the default or an explicit set, you could omit the From value, the animation would use the implicit starting value, and the result would be the same.
segment.target: Note For the example we showed, if you were sure that the starting state of the object being animated has **Opacity** always equal to 1, either through the default or an explicit set, you could omit the From value, the animation would use the implicit starting value, and the result would be the same.

segment.source: From/To/By are nullable
segment.target: From/To/By are nullable

segment.source: We mentioned previously that you can omit From, To or By and thus use current non-animated values as substitutes for a missing value.
segment.target: We mentioned previously that you can omit From, To or By and thus use current non-animated values as substitutes for a missing value.

segment.source: From, To or By properties of an animation aren't of the type you might guess.
segment.target: From, To or By properties of an animation aren't of the type you might guess.

segment.source: For example the type of the **DoubleAnimation.To** property isn't **Double**.
segment.target: For example the type of the **DoubleAnimation.To** property isn't **Double**.

segment.source: Instead it's a **Nullable** for Double.
segment.target: Instead it's a **Nullable** for Double.

segment.source: And its default value is null, not 0.
segment.target: And its default value is null, not 0.

segment.source: That null value is how the animation system distinguishes that you haven't specifically set a value for a From, To or By property.
segment.target: That null value is how the animation system distinguishes that you haven't specifically set a value for a From, To or By property.

segment.source: Visual C++ component extensions (C++/CX) doesn't have a Nullable type, so it uses **IReference** instead.
segment.target: Visual C++ component extensions (C++/CX) doesn't have a Nullable type, so it uses **IReference** instead.

segment.source: Other properties of an animation
segment.target: Other properties of an animation

segment.source: The next properties described in this section are all optional in that they have defaults that are appropriate for most animations.
segment.target: The next properties described in this section are all optional in that they have defaults that are appropriate for most animations.

segment.source: If you don't specify either **AutoReverse** or **RepeatBehavior** on an animation, that animation will run once, and run for the time as specified as the **Duration**.
segment.target: If you don't specify either **AutoReverse** or **RepeatBehavior** on an animation, that animation will run once, and run for the time as specified as the **Duration**.

segment.source: The **AutoReverse** property specifies whether a timeline plays in reverse after it reaches the end of its **Duration**.
segment.target: The **AutoReverse** property specifies whether a timeline plays in reverse after it reaches the end of its **Duration**.

segment.source: If you set it to true, the animation reverses after it reaches the end of its declared **Duration**, changing the value from its ending value (To) back to its starting value (From).
segment.target: If you set it to true, the animation reverses after it reaches the end of its declared **Duration**, changing the value from its ending value (To) back to its starting value (From).

segment.source: This means that the animation effectively runs for double the time of its **Duration**.
segment.target: This means that the animation effectively runs for double the time of its **Duration**.

segment.source: The **RepeatBehavior** property specifies either how many times a timeline plays, or a larger duration that the timeline should repeat within.
segment.target: The **RepeatBehavior** property specifies either how many times a timeline plays, or a larger duration that the timeline should repeat within.

segment.source: By default, a timeline has an iteration count of "1x", which means it plays one time for its **Duration** and does not repeat.
segment.target: By default, a timeline has an iteration count of "1x", which means it plays one time for its **Duration** and does not repeat.

segment.source: You can cause the animation to run multiple iterations, for example a value of "3x" causes the animation to run three times.
segment.target: You can cause the animation to run multiple iterations, for example a value of "3x" causes the animation to run three times.

segment.source: Or, you can specify a different **Duration** for **RepeatBehavior**.
segment.target: Or, you can specify a different **Duration** for **RepeatBehavior**.

segment.source: That Duration should be longer than the Duration of the animation itself to be effective.
segment.target: That Duration should be longer than the Duration of the animation itself to be effective.

segment.source: For example, if you specify a RepeatBehavior of "0:0:10", for an animation that has a **Duration** of "0:0:2", that animation repeats five times.
segment.target: For example, if you specify a RepeatBehavior of "0:0:10", for an animation that has a **Duration** of "0:0:2", that animation repeats five times.

segment.source: If these don't divide evenly, the animation gets truncated at the time that the RepeatBehavior time is reached, which might be partway through.
segment.target: If these don't divide evenly, the animation gets truncated at the time that the RepeatBehavior time is reached, which might be partway through.

segment.source: Finally you can specify the special value "Forever", which causes the animation to run infinitely until it's deliberately stopped.
segment.target: Finally you can specify the special value "Forever", which causes the animation to run infinitely until it's deliberately stopped.

segment.source: For more info about **RepeatBehavior** values and the XAML syntax, see **RepeatBehavior**.
segment.target: For more info about **RepeatBehavior** values and the XAML syntax, see **RepeatBehavior**.

segment.source: By default, when an animation ends, the animation leaves the property value as the final To or By-modified value even after its duration is surpassed.
segment.target: By default, when an animation ends, the animation leaves the property value as the final To or By-modified value even after its duration is surpassed.

segment.source: However, if you set the value of the **FillBehavior** property to **FillBehavior.Stop**, the value of the animated value reverts to whatever the value was before the animation was applied, or more precisely to the current effective value as determined by the dependency property system (for more info on this distinction, see Dependency properties overview.
segment.target: However, if you set the value of the **FillBehavior** property to **FillBehavior.Stop**, the value of the animated value reverts to whatever the value was before the animation was applied, or more precisely to the current effective value as determined by the dependency property system (for more info on this distinction, see Dependency properties overview.

segment.source: By default, the **BeginTime** of an animation is "0:0:0", so it begins as soon as its containing **Storyboard** runs.
segment.target: By default, the **BeginTime** of an animation is "0:0:0", so it begins as soon as its containing **Storyboard** runs.

segment.source: You might change this if the Storyboard contains more than one animation and you want to stagger the start times of the others versus an initial animation, or to create a deliberate short delay.
segment.target: You might change this if the Storyboard contains more than one animation and you want to stagger the start times of the others versus an initial animation, or to create a deliberate short delay.

segment.source: If you have more than one animation in a **Storyboard** you can change the time rate of one or more of the animations relative to the Storyboard.
segment.target: If you have more than one animation in a **Storyboard** you can change the time rate of one or more of the animations relative to the Storyboard.

segment.source: It's the parent Storyboard that ultimately controls how the **Duration** time elapses while the animations run.
segment.target: It's the parent Storyboard that ultimately controls how the **Duration** time elapses while the animations run.

segment.source: This property isn't used very often.
segment.target: This property isn't used very often.

segment.source: For more info see **SpeedRatio**.
segment.target: For more info see **SpeedRatio**.

segment.source: Defining more than one animation in a Storyboard
segment.target: Defining more than one animation in a Storyboard

segment.source: The contents of a **Storyboard** can be more than one animation definition.
segment.target: The contents of a **Storyboard** can be more than one animation definition.

segment.source: You might have more than one animation if you are applying related animations to two properties of the same target object.
segment.target: You might have more than one animation if you are applying related animations to two properties of the same target object.

segment.source: For example, you might change both the **TranslateX** and **TranslateY** properties of a **TranslateTransform** used as the **RenderTransform** of a UI element; this will cause the element to translate diagonally.
segment.target: For example, you might change both the **TranslateX** and **TranslateY** properties of a **TranslateTransform** used as the **RenderTransform** of a UI element; this will cause the element to translate diagonally.

segment.source: You need two different animations to accomplish that, but you might want the animations to be part of the same Storyboard because you always want those two animations to be run together.
segment.target: You need two different animations to accomplish that, but you might want the animations to be part of the same Storyboard because you always want those two animations to be run together.

segment.source: The animations don't have to be the same type, or target the same object.
segment.target: The animations don't have to be the same type, or target the same object.

segment.source: They can have different durations, and don't have to share any property values.
segment.target: They can have different durations, and don't have to share any property values.

segment.source: When the parent **Storyboard** runs, each of the animations within will run too.
segment.target: When the parent **Storyboard** runs, each of the animations within will run too.

segment.source: The **Storyboard** class actually has a lot of the same animation properties as the animation types do, because both share the **Timeline** base class.
segment.target: The **Storyboard** class actually has a lot of the same animation properties as the animation types do, because both share the **Timeline** base class.

segment.source: Thus, a Storyboard can have a **RepeatBehavior**, or a **BeginTime**.
segment.target: Thus, a Storyboard can have a **RepeatBehavior**, or a **BeginTime**.

segment.source: You don't usually set these on a Storyboard though unless you want all the contained animations to have that behavior.
segment.target: You don't usually set these on a Storyboard though unless you want all the contained animations to have that behavior.

segment.source: As a general rule, any Timeline property as set on a Storyboard applies to all its child animations.
segment.target: As a general rule, any Timeline property as set on a Storyboard applies to all its child animations.

segment.source: If let unset, the Storyboard has an implicit duration that's calculated from the longest **Duration** value of the contained animations.
segment.target: If let unset, the Storyboard has an implicit duration that's calculated from the longest **Duration** value of the contained animations.

segment.source: An explicitly set **Duration** on a Storyboard that's shorter than one of its child animations will cause that animation to get cut off, which isn't usually desirable.
segment.target: An explicitly set **Duration** on a Storyboard that's shorter than one of its child animations will cause that animation to get cut off, which isn't usually desirable.

segment.source: A storyboard can't contain two animations that attempt to target and animate the same property on the same object.
segment.target: A storyboard can't contain two animations that attempt to target and animate the same property on the same object.

segment.source: If you try this, you'll get a runtime error when the storyboard tries to run.
segment.target: If you try this, you'll get a runtime error when the storyboard tries to run.

segment.source: This restriction applies even if the animations don't overlap in time because of deliberately different **BeginTime** values and durations.
segment.target: This restriction applies even if the animations don't overlap in time because of deliberately different **BeginTime** values and durations.

segment.source: If you really want to apply a more complex animation timeline to the same property in a single storyboard, the way to do this is to use a key-frame animation.
segment.target: If you really want to apply a more complex animation timeline to the same property in a single storyboard, the way to do this is to use a key-frame animation.

segment.source: See Key-frame and easing function animations.
segment.target: See Key-frame and easing function animations.

segment.source: The animation system can apply more than one animation to the value of a property, if those inputs come from multiple storyboards.
segment.target: The animation system can apply more than one animation to the value of a property, if those inputs come from multiple storyboards.

segment.source: Using this behavior deliberately for simultaneously running storyboards isn't common.
segment.target: Using this behavior deliberately for simultaneously running storyboards isn't common.

segment.source: However it's possible that an app-defined animation that you apply to a control property will be modifying the HoldEnd value of an animation that was previously run as part of the control's visual state model.
segment.target: However it's possible that an app-defined animation that you apply to a control property will be modifying the HoldEnd value of an animation that was previously run as part of the control's visual state model.

segment.source: Defining a storyboard as a resource
segment.target: Defining a storyboard as a resource

segment.source: A **Storyboard** is the container that you put animation objects in.
segment.target: A **Storyboard** is the container that you put animation objects in.

segment.source: You typically define the Storyboard as a resource that is available to the object that you want to animate, either in page-level **Resources** or **Application.Resources**.
segment.target: You typically define the Storyboard as a resource that is available to the object that you want to animate, either in page-level **Resources** or **Application.Resources**.

segment.source: This next example shows how the previous example **Storyboard** would be contained in a page-level **Resources** definition, where the Storyboard is a keyed resource of the root **Page**.
segment.target: This next example shows how the previous example **Storyboard** would be contained in a page-level **Resources** definition, where the Storyboard is a keyed resource of the root **Page**.

segment.source: Note the x:Name attribute.
segment.target: Note the x:Name attribute.

segment.source: This attribute is how you define a variable name for the Storyboard, so that other elements in XAML as well as code can refer to the Storyboard later.
segment.target: This attribute is how you define a variable name for the Storyboard, so that other elements in XAML as well as code can refer to the Storyboard later.

segment.source: Defining resources at the XAML root of a XAML file such as page.xaml or app.xaml is a common practice for how to organize keyed resources in your XAML.
segment.target: Defining resources at the XAML root of a XAML file such as page.xaml or app.xaml is a common practice for how to organize keyed resources in your XAML.

segment.source: You also can factor resources into separate files and merge them into apps or pages.
segment.target: You also can factor resources into separate files and merge them into apps or pages.

segment.source: For more info, see ResourceDictionary and XAML resource references.
segment.target: For more info, see ResourceDictionary and XAML resource references.

segment.source: Note Windows Runtime XAML supports identifying resources either using the x:Key attribute or the x:Name attribute.
segment.target: Note Windows Runtime XAML supports identifying resources either using the x:Key attribute or the x:Name attribute.

segment.source: Using x:Name attribute is more common for a **Storyboard**, because you'll want to reference it by variable name eventually, so that you can call its **Begin** method and run the animations.
segment.target: Using x:Name attribute is more common for a **Storyboard**, because you'll want to reference it by variable name eventually, so that you can call its **Begin** method and run the animations.

segment.source: If you do use x:Key attribute, you'll need to use **ResourceDictionary** methods such as the **Item** indexer to retrieve it as a keyed resource and then cast the retrieved object to Storyboard to use the Storyboard methods.
segment.target: If you do use x:Key attribute, you'll need to use **ResourceDictionary** methods such as the **Item** indexer to retrieve it as a keyed resource and then cast the retrieved object to Storyboard to use the Storyboard methods.

segment.source: You also put your animations within a **Storyboard** unit when you are declaring the visual state animations for a control's visual appearance.
segment.target: You also put your animations within a **Storyboard** unit when you are declaring the visual state animations for a control's visual appearance.

segment.source: In that case the Storyboard elements you define go into a **VisualState** container that's nested more deeply in a **Style** (it's the Style that is the keyed resource).
segment.target: In that case the Storyboard elements you define go into a **VisualState** container that's nested more deeply in a **Style** (it's the Style that is the keyed resource).

segment.source: You don't need a key or name for your Storyboard in this case because it's the VisualState that has a target name that the **VisualStateManager** can invoke.
segment.target: You don't need a key or name for your Storyboard in this case because it's the VisualState that has a target name that the **VisualStateManager** can invoke.

segment.source: The styles for controls are often factored into separate XAML **ResourceDictionary** files rather than placed in a page or app Resources collection.
segment.target: The styles for controls are often factored into separate XAML **ResourceDictionary** files rather than placed in a page or app Resources collection.

segment.source: For more info, see Storyboarded animations for visual states.
segment.target: For more info, see Storyboarded animations for visual states.

segment.source: Dependent and independent animations
segment.target: Dependent and independent animations

segment.source: At this point we need to introduce some important points about how the animation system works.
segment.target: At this point we need to introduce some important points about how the animation system works.

segment.source: In particular, animation interacts fundamentally with how a Windows Runtime app renders to the screen, and how that rendering uses processing threads.
segment.target: In particular, animation interacts fundamentally with how a Windows Runtime app renders to the screen, and how that rendering uses processing threads.

segment.source: A Windows Runtime app always has a main UI thread, and this thread is responsible for updating the screen with current information.
segment.target: A Windows Runtime app always has a main UI thread, and this thread is responsible for updating the screen with current information.

segment.source: In addition, a Windows Runtime app has a composition thread, which is used for precalculating layouts immediately before they are shown.
segment.target: In addition, a Windows Runtime app has a composition thread, which is used for precalculating layouts immediately before they are shown.

segment.source: When you animate the UI, there's potential to cause a lot of work for the UI thread.
segment.target: When you animate the UI, there's potential to cause a lot of work for the UI thread.

segment.source: The system must redraw large areas of the screen using fairly short time intervals between each refresh.
segment.target: The system must redraw large areas of the screen using fairly short time intervals between each refresh.

segment.source: This is necessary for capturing the latest property value of the animated property.
segment.target: This is necessary for capturing the latest property value of the animated property.

segment.source: If you're not careful, there's risk that an animation can make the UI less responsive, or will impact performance of other app features that are also on the same UI thread.
segment.target: If you're not careful, there's risk that an animation can make the UI less responsive, or will impact performance of other app features that are also on the same UI thread.

segment.source: The variety of animation that is determined to have some risk of slowing down the UI thread is called a dependent animation.
segment.target: The variety of animation that is determined to have some risk of slowing down the UI thread is called a dependent animation.

segment.source: An animation not subject to this risk is an independent animation.
segment.target: An animation not subject to this risk is an independent animation.

segment.source: The distinction between dependent and independent animations isn't just determined by animation types (**DoubleAnimation** and so on) as we described earlier.
segment.target: The distinction between dependent and independent animations isn't just determined by animation types (**DoubleAnimation** and so on) as we described earlier.

segment.source: Instead, it's determined by which specific properties you are animating, and other factors like inheritance and composition of controls.
segment.target: Instead, it's determined by which specific properties you are animating, and other factors like inheritance and composition of controls.

segment.source: There are circumstances where even if an animation does change UI, the animation can have minimal impact to the UI thread, and can instead be handled by the composition thread as an independent animation.
segment.target: There are circumstances where even if an animation does change UI, the animation can have minimal impact to the UI thread, and can instead be handled by the composition thread as an independent animation.

segment.source: An animation is independent if it has any of these characteristics:
segment.target: An animation is independent if it has any of these characteristics:

segment.source: The **Duration** of the animation is 0 seconds (see Caution)
segment.target: The **Duration** of the animation is 0 seconds (see Caution)

segment.source: The animation targets **UIElement.Opacity**
segment.target: The animation targets **UIElement.Opacity**

segment.source: The animation targets a sub-property value of these **UIElement** properties: **RenderTransform**, **Projection**, **Clip**
segment.target: The animation targets a sub-property value of these **UIElement** properties: **RenderTransform**, **Projection**, **Clip**

segment.source: The animation targets **Canvas.Left** or **Canvas.Top**
segment.target: The animation targets **Canvas.Left** or **Canvas.Top**

segment.source: The animation targets a **Brush** value and uses a **SolidColorBrush**, animating its **Color**
segment.target: The animation targets a **Brush** value and uses a **SolidColorBrush**, animating its **Color**

segment.source: The animation is an **ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames**
segment.target: The animation is an **ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames**

segment.source: Caution In order for your animation to be treated as independent, you must explicitly set Duration="0".
segment.target: Caution In order for your animation to be treated as independent, you must explicitly set Duration="0".

segment.source: For example, if you remove Duration="0" from this XAML, the animation is treated as dependent, even though the **KeyTime** of the frame is "0:0:0".
segment.target: For example, if you remove Duration="0" from this XAML, the animation is treated as dependent, even though the **KeyTime** of the frame is "0:0:0".

segment.source: If your animation doesn't meet these criteria, it's probably a dependent animation.
segment.target: If your animation doesn't meet these criteria, it's probably a dependent animation.

segment.source: By default, the animation system won't run a dependent animation.
segment.target: By default, the animation system won't run a dependent animation.

segment.source: So during the process of developing and testing, you might not even be seeing your animation running.
segment.target: So during the process of developing and testing, you might not even be seeing your animation running.

segment.source: You can still use this animation, but you must specifically enable each such dependent animation.
segment.target: You can still use this animation, but you must specifically enable each such dependent animation.

segment.source: To enable your animation, set the EnableDependentAnimation property of the animation object to true.
segment.target: To enable your animation, set the EnableDependentAnimation property of the animation object to true.

segment.source: (Each **Timeline** subclass that represents an animation has a different implementation of the property but they're all named EnableDependentAnimation.)
segment.target: (Each **Timeline** subclass that represents an animation has a different implementation of the property but they're all named EnableDependentAnimation.)

segment.source: The requirement of enabling dependent animations falling onto the app developer is a conscious design aspect of the animation system and the development experience.
segment.target: The requirement of enabling dependent animations falling onto the app developer is a conscious design aspect of the animation system and the development experience.

segment.source: We want developers to be aware that animations do have a performance cost for the responsiveness of your UI.
segment.target: We want developers to be aware that animations do have a performance cost for the responsiveness of your UI.

segment.source: Poorly performing animations are difficult to isolate and debug in a full-scale app.
segment.target: Poorly performing animations are difficult to isolate and debug in a full-scale app.

segment.source: So it's better to turn on only the dependent animations you really need for your app's UI experience.
segment.target: So it's better to turn on only the dependent animations you really need for your app's UI experience.

segment.source: We didn't want to make too easy to compromise your app's performance because of decorative animations that use a lot of cycles.
segment.target: We didn't want to make too easy to compromise your app's performance because of decorative animations that use a lot of cycles.

segment.source: For more info on performance tips for animation, see Optimize animations and media.
segment.target: For more info on performance tips for animation, see Optimize animations and media.

segment.source: As an app developer, you can also choose to apply an app-wide setting that always disables dependent animations, even those where EnableDependentAnimation is true.
segment.target: As an app developer, you can also choose to apply an app-wide setting that always disables dependent animations, even those where EnableDependentAnimation is true.

segment.source: See **Timeline.AllowDependentAnimations**.
segment.target: See **Timeline.AllowDependentAnimations**.

segment.source: Tip If you are composing visual states for a control using Visual Studio, the designer will produce warnings whenever you attempt to apply a dependent animation to a visual state property.
segment.target: Tip If you are composing visual states for a control using Visual Studio, the designer will produce warnings whenever you attempt to apply a dependent animation to a visual state property.

segment.source: Starting and controlling an animation
segment.target: Starting and controlling an animation

segment.source: Everything we've shown you so far doesn't actually cause an animation to run or be applied!
segment.target: Everything we've shown you so far doesn't actually cause an animation to run or be applied!

segment.source: Until the animation is started and is running, the value changes that an animation is declaring in XAML are latent and won't happen yet.
segment.target: Until the animation is started and is running, the value changes that an animation is declaring in XAML are latent and won't happen yet.

segment.source: You must explicitly start an animation in some way that's related to the app lifetime or the user experience.
segment.target: You must explicitly start an animation in some way that's related to the app lifetime or the user experience.

segment.source: At the simplest level, you start an animation by calling the **Begin** method on the **Storyboard** that's the parent for that animation.
segment.target: At the simplest level, you start an animation by calling the **Begin** method on the **Storyboard** that's the parent for that animation.

segment.source: You can't call methods from XAML directly, so whatever you do to enable your animations, you'll be doing it from code.
segment.target: You can't call methods from XAML directly, so whatever you do to enable your animations, you'll be doing it from code.

segment.source: That will either be the code-behind for the pages or components of your app, or perhaps the logic of your control if you're defining a custom control class.
segment.target: That will either be the code-behind for the pages or components of your app, or perhaps the logic of your control if you're defining a custom control class.

segment.source: Typically, you'll call **Begin** and just let the animation run to its duration completion.
segment.target: Typically, you'll call **Begin** and just let the animation run to its duration completion.

segment.source: However, you can also use **Pause**, **Resume** and **Stop** methods to control the **Storyboard** at run-time, as well as other APIs that are used for more advanced animation control scenarios.
segment.target: However, you can also use **Pause**, **Resume** and **Stop** methods to control the **Storyboard** at run-time, as well as other APIs that are used for more advanced animation control scenarios.

segment.source: When you call **Begin** on a storyboard that contain animations that repeat infinitely (RepeatBehavior="Forever") that animation runs until the page containing it is unloaded, or you specifically call **Pause** or **Stop**.
segment.target: When you call **Begin** on a storyboard that contain animations that repeat infinitely (RepeatBehavior="Forever") that animation runs until the page containing it is unloaded, or you specifically call **Pause** or **Stop**.

segment.source: Starting an animation from app code
segment.target: Starting an animation from app code

segment.source: You can either start animations automatically, or in response to user actions.
segment.target: You can either start animations automatically, or in response to user actions.

segment.source: For the automatic case, you typically use an object lifetime event such as **Loaded** to act as the animation trigger.
segment.target: For the automatic case, you typically use an object lifetime event such as **Loaded** to act as the animation trigger.

segment.source: The Loaded event is a good event to use for this because at that point the UI is ready for interaction, and the animation won't be cut off at the beginning because another part of UI was still loading.
segment.target: The Loaded event is a good event to use for this because at that point the UI is ready for interaction, and the animation won't be cut off at the beginning because another part of UI was still loading.

segment.source: In this example, the **PointerPressed** event is attached to the rectangle so that when the user clicks the rectangle, the animation begins.
segment.target: In this example, the **PointerPressed** event is attached to the rectangle so that when the user clicks the rectangle, the animation begins.

segment.source: The event handler start the **Storyboard** (the animation) by using the **Begin** method of the Storyboard.
segment.target: The event handler start the **Storyboard** (the animation) by using the **Begin** method of the Storyboard.

segment.source: You can handle the **Completed** event if you want other logic to run after the animation has finished applying values.
segment.target: You can handle the **Completed** event if you want other logic to run after the animation has finished applying values.

segment.source: Also, for troubleshooting property system/animation interactions, the **GetAnimationBaseValue** method can be useful.
segment.target: Also, for troubleshooting property system/animation interactions, the **GetAnimationBaseValue** method can be useful.

segment.source: Tip Whenever you are coding for an app scenario where you are starting an animation from app code, you might want to review again whether an animation or transition already exists in the animation library for your UI scenario.
segment.target: Tip Whenever you are coding for an app scenario where you are starting an animation from app code, you might want to review again whether an animation or transition already exists in the animation library for your UI scenario.

segment.source: The library animations enable a more consistent UI experience across all Windows Runtime apps, and are easier to use.
segment.target: The library animations enable a more consistent UI experience across all Windows Runtime apps, and are easier to use.

segment.source: Animations for visual states
segment.target: Animations for visual states

segment.source: The run behavior for a **Storyboard** that's used to define a control's visual state is different from how an app might run a storyboard directly.
segment.target: The run behavior for a **Storyboard** that's used to define a control's visual state is different from how an app might run a storyboard directly.

segment.source: As applied to a visual state definition in XAML, the Storyboard is an element of a containing **VisualState**, and the state as a whole is controlled by using the **VisualStateManager** API.
segment.target: As applied to a visual state definition in XAML, the Storyboard is an element of a containing **VisualState**, and the state as a whole is controlled by using the **VisualStateManager** API.

segment.source: Any animations within will run according to their animation values and **Timeline** properties when the containing VisualState is used by a control.
segment.target: Any animations within will run according to their animation values and **Timeline** properties when the containing VisualState is used by a control.

segment.source: For more info, see Storyboards for visual states.
segment.target: For more info, see Storyboards for visual states.

segment.source: For visual states, the apparent **FillBehavior** is different.
segment.target: For visual states, the apparent **FillBehavior** is different.

segment.source: If a visual state is changed to another state, all the property changes applied by the previous visual state and its animations are canceled, even if the new visual state doesn't specifically apply a new animation to a property.
segment.target: If a visual state is changed to another state, all the property changes applied by the previous visual state and its animations are canceled, even if the new visual state doesn't specifically apply a new animation to a property.

segment.source: Storyboard and EventTrigger
segment.target: Storyboard and EventTrigger

segment.source: There is one way to start an animation that can be declared entirely in XAML.
segment.target: There is one way to start an animation that can be declared entirely in XAML.

segment.source: However, this technique isn't widely used anymore.
segment.target: However, this technique isn't widely used anymore.

segment.source: It's a legacy syntax from WPF and early versions of Silverlight prior to **VisualStateManager** support.
segment.target: It's a legacy syntax from WPF and early versions of Silverlight prior to **VisualStateManager** support.

segment.source: This **EventTrigger** syntax still works in Windows Runtime XAML for import/compatibility reasons, but only works for a trigger behavior based on the **FrameworkElement.Loaded** event; attempting to trigger off other events will throw exceptions or fail to compile.
segment.target: This **EventTrigger** syntax still works in Windows Runtime XAML for import/compatibility reasons, but only works for a trigger behavior based on the **FrameworkElement.Loaded** event; attempting to trigger off other events will throw exceptions or fail to compile.

segment.source: For more info, see **EventTrigger** or **BeginStoryboard**.
segment.target: For more info, see **EventTrigger** or **BeginStoryboard**.

segment.source: Animating XAML attached properties
segment.target: Animating XAML attached properties

segment.source: It's not a common scenario, but you can apply an animated value to a XAML attached property.
segment.target: It's not a common scenario, but you can apply an animated value to a XAML attached property.

segment.source: For more info on what attached properties are and how they work, see Attached properties overview.
segment.target: For more info on what attached properties are and how they work, see Attached properties overview.

segment.source: Targeting an attached property requires a property-path syntax that encloses the property name in parentheses.
segment.target: Targeting an attached property requires a property-path syntax that encloses the property name in parentheses.

segment.source: You can animate the built-in attached properties such as **Canvas.ZIndex** by using an **ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames** that applies discrete integer values.
segment.target: You can animate the built-in attached properties such as **Canvas.ZIndex** by using an **ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames** that applies discrete integer values.

segment.source: However, an existing limitation of the Windows Runtime XAML implementation is that you cannot animate a custom attached property.
segment.target: However, an existing limitation of the Windows Runtime XAML implementation is that you cannot animate a custom attached property.

segment.source: More animation types, and next steps for learning about animating your UI
segment.target: More animation types, and next steps for learning about animating your UI

segment.source: Up to now, we've shown the custom animations that are animating between two values, and then linearly interpolating the values as necessary while the animation runs.
segment.target: Up to now, we've shown the custom animations that are animating between two values, and then linearly interpolating the values as necessary while the animation runs.

segment.source: These are called From/To/By animations.
segment.target: These are called From/To/By animations.

segment.source: But there's another animation type that enables you to declare intermediate values that fall between the start and end.
segment.target: But there's another animation type that enables you to declare intermediate values that fall between the start and end.

segment.source: These are called key-frame animations.
segment.target: These are called key-frame animations.

segment.source: There's also a way to alter the interpolation logic on either a From/To/By animation or a key-frame animation.
segment.target: There's also a way to alter the interpolation logic on either a From/To/By animation or a key-frame animation.

segment.source: This involves applying an easing function.
segment.target: This involves applying an easing function.

segment.source: For more info on these concepts, see Key-frame and easing function animations.
segment.target: For more info on these concepts, see Key-frame and easing function animations.

segment.source: Related topics
segment.target: Related topics
